huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
If you obtain a general-season archery elk permit, you may use archery equipment to take only one of the following animals:
•One elk of either sex on a general-season any bull elk unit
•An antlerless elk or a spike bull elk on a general-season spike bull elk unit
•Only a spike bull on the Book Cliffs unit
•One elk of either sex on the extended archery elk areas

A spike bull is a bull elk which has at least one antler beam with no branching above the ears. Branched means a projection on an antler longer than one inch, measured from its base to its tip.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: ~~~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
This is an early season hunt. Elk key in on water during this time of year, but priorities will shift towards breeding as the season progresses. Towards the end of the hunt the rut will be starting up, and elk may be vocal, making them easier to locate. Look for spikes with cow groups and older bulls in small bachelor groups until the rut when they will join cow groups.

Going the extra mile and getting away from roads and other hunters is a good way to increase your odds of success on this hunt. Finding a good vantage point and glassing early and late is a good strategy this time of year. At the beginning of this hunt, temperatures are high, forcing elk to bed in cover for most of the day. Sitting on water holes is also an effective hunt strategy.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
Most hunters plan on spending five days hunting in this remote area.  There are plenty of water sources so don’t plan on bringing much water in with you.  Some hunters who do not have much horse experience camp at the trail heads and hike in and out every day.  There are several guides and outfitters who work in this area.  I would plan on a very challenging and rewarding hunt.  Not many hunters can say they have killed a trophy bull in the true back country like this unit can provide.  

Currently there is no cattle grazing in this area, to allow stream bank restoration, and let the landscape heal after the massive fire.  There are native Colorado cutthroat trout in most of the streams.  There are 30-40 wild horses in this area.  I have seen anywhere from 30-70 bison on this unit.  It is not uncommon to see black bears in this area.  There is usually plenty of feed for horses, most sportsman hobble their horses; for a few hours a day.  

This area is patrolled quite frequently by DWR personnel.  Keep this in mind when you are transporting your game.  Try to make it easy to access the permit and tag on the animal.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access.  Cellular phone coverage is very spotty on this hunt unit.  Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers.  Satellite phones do work in the area.  The Biologist suggests handheld radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

The Book Cliffs roadless area has a high bear population.  I recommend keeping a clean camp and putting your garbage in a place that is inaccessible to bears. If you do have problems with bears please report them to the DWR Northeast Regional Office as soon as possible (435 781-9453), or local the local dispatch center (435 789-4222).      

The Book Cliffs mountain range is one of the more remote areas in Utah.  The trails are very steep and challenging.  Every year sportsmen kill horses and mules in the roadless area.  I would suggest bringing horses that are in good physical condition.    

It is not uncommon to have thunderstorms, flash floods and have trails wash out.  If it rains hard it makes it difficult to navigate the trails, and the access roads.  Tire chains can come in very handy.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  Thunder storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region.  Most hunters struggle with meat spoiling in the heat.  I would plan on hot weather and plan accordingly.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 0~7500 (entire Book Cliffs unit)~5500 (entire Book Cliffs unit)~~~~~~~4~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest:  The roadless area has four main drainages: West Willow Creek, She Creek, Little Creek, and East Willow Creek.  All of these drainages are good for camping.  The ridges that separate the drainages are: Went Ridge, and Little Creek Ridge.  There is a spring on Little Creek Ridge called Three Springs that has good drinking water.  This is a popular elk hunting area.  Other popular areas to find elk are: Santio Knolls, One Eye Canyon, Rivoguts Canyon, Fish Creek, and Dry Fork Canyon.  

The elk are found more on the tops of the ridges and come down on the faces and in the canyons to feed and drink.  Most archery hunters have the most success early in the hunt sitting remote water holes.  As the hunt progress the elk start to rut and become easier to spot and stalk.   

Migration Patterns:  During the archery hunt I would expect to see large herds of cows, calves, and spike bulls.  The bulls will start breaking up from their bachelor herds.  If there isn’t much pressure in the bottom of the canyons I would expect to see elk coming out in the evenings to drink from the creeks.  You will find elk from one end of the roadless area to the other.  The elk will start feeling pressured towards the end of the hunt with increased rifle hunters scouting for their upcoming hunt.  Little Creek Ridge consistently holds a lot of elk.  

Scouting Tips:  A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential for scouting elk in this area.  Scouting is most effective mid-summer.  If you are able to place trail cameras on the remote springs and water holes you will be able to pattern the movements of the bulls.  In the hot early fall temperatures I would expect to see the most animals at prime time (1/2 hour before dawn and an hour before sunset).  There are several recovering burned areas that have produced large amounts of grass that is excellent for elk. Elk spend a lot of time in the aspen patches where there is a good understory of grass and forbs.       

There are very few signs on the trails.  I would bring a good map, compass, GPS, and if possible someone who is familiar with the area.  If you have never set foot in this unit, it might appear small on a map but on the ground it is quite a large area.  

Behavior:  Once the bulls shed their velvet they will start to break up from their winter and summer bachelor herds.  They will usually water at least two times a day.  It is not unusual for elk to graze through the night.  As the hunt progresses and if colder weather moves in, the elk will start to come into the rut, or breeding season.  Before they start to herd the cows up the bulls are very susceptible to cow elk calls.  I have had success calling bulls in from far distances in the unit with the use of a cow call in early September.  As elk get closer to the rut they will become more vocal and will start to round up small herds of cows.  The larger bulls will usually try to keep their cows away from contending bulls.  It is normal to have one herd bull and other bulls surrounding the cows at a distance.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This unit is mainly private land.  Some public ground where  elk have been seen is south and west of Snowville on Cedar Hill and Wildcat Hill.  Camping outside of official campgrounds is permitted on most of the public lands that are accessible to the general public. Vehicle access to most of the unit is limited as it is comprised mainly of Private land.  Access to areas that elk frequent are best reached by non-motorized travel.  Most areas are closed to off road vehicle use except on designated routes.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Cellular phone coverage is good on this hunt unit.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and hunt, and when you will return.  Full services are available in Snowville and Tremonton.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, snow, wind and heat.  Be very cautious of lightning while hunting on high ridges or exposed slopes.  Early fall snow storms occur occasionally in this area.  Most years the snow will melt off within a day or two until through the first week of October.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 16.7~675 (entire Box Elder unit)~700 (entire Box Elder unit)~~~~~~~26~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Elk on the unit summer near water that is associated with irrigated agriculture. Late summer temperatures can reach 100 degrees in this area forcing elk to find trees near water.  Elk will move back and forth across the Utah/Idaho state lines, and during heavy snow years, more elk will migrate south out of Idaho. During the hunting season elk will be found near and on irrigated agriculture where heavy juniper borders the fields.  Glassing during early morning and evenings is critical to find these groups of elk.  It is imperative that hunters get off the roads either on foot or by horse or mule if they wish to observe bulls.   Areas to begin scouting include Sage Valley, Hansel Valley, and east of Snowville to Blue Creek.  Elk have also been found on Cedar Hill and Wildcat Hill south and west of Snowville.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Elk on this unit are primarily found on private property. Landowners will allow access but will charge trespass fees.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Back country safety considerations should be observed.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Weather is usually warm and precautions should be taken to avoid spoilage of harvested animals.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 8.0 (entire Cache unit)~2300 (entire Cache unit)~3350 (entire Cache unit)~~~~~~~644 (entire Cache unit)~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Most elk are found on private land in Round Valley on the west benches. Hunters should secure access before applying for this hunt. Landowners will ask for trespass fees for access to their property.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Central Mtns Manti is a Spike Only Unit. The Manti is the largest elk herd in the state.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat. It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon. Be very cautious of lightening while hunting on high ridges. Early fall snow storms occur regularly in this area. Most years the snow will melt off, within a day or two until the first week of October.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 9.7~12000~9900~~~~~~~1018~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: For the most part the elk will not show any migratory behavior during the archery, muzzleloader, and early rifle hunts. These elk will remain on summer ranges at elevations generally above 8,000 feet. Bulls will begin to migrate by the Late Season Any Weapon Hunt. Most bulls tend to move down in elevation on to steep ridges predominated by mountain mahogany shrubs. About 90% of the elk move east to winter and spend the winter months on the ridges west of SR-10

Scouting Tips: You can not go terribly wrong on this unit. There is excellent access to most of the unit. A popular route to learn the unit is Skyline Drive. Skyline Drive runs along the spine of the mountain range and provides access to most of the high elevation habitat on the entire unit. Learn country! There are over 12,000 elk on this mountain so there are small groups of elk with bulls in nearly every canyon with good habitat on the mountain. Listen for bugling activity and cow calls to locate elk. Also listen for domestic sheep. There are an abundance of sheep that will still be on the mountain during the September hunts. If you can hear sheep in the canyon below you, it is best to move to the next canyon as elk and sheep are rarely found in the same vicinity it seems.

Behavior: As with most big game animals the early mornings and evenings are the best times to find elk. This is when most rutting activity will take place as well. Glass the open south facing slopes where elk like to feed or small meadows near the canyon bottoms. Most spike bulls will be with cows during this hunt.

Elk rut: There will typically be a little rutting activity starting the first part of September, with the peak of the rut being September 15th-the end of September. There will still be some rutting activity in October, but it will be winding down by then.

Recommended Areas: Upper Fish Creek and it's tributaries. The tributaries include Gooseberry Creek, Silver Creek, C Canyon, and the Straight Fork. This is a roadless area on the north end of the unit. This area typically holds a lot of elk and had some prescribed fires recently that has improved elk habitat. It can be accessed from North Skyline Drive on the west or from Scofield Reservoir on the east. The bottom two miles of Upper Fish Creek is privately owned and in a CWMU Bear Ridge and Fish Creek Ridge These ridges have roads going down them. They are northwest of Scofield Reservoir. The bottom 2 miles of these ridges are privately owned. This is excellent habitat in the Pondtown Creek drainage on the north end of the unit. It is best accessed from North Skyline Drive. Trough Spring Ridge This is accessed off of SR-264 southwest of the town of Scofield. It is just above the Skyline Coal Mine. This is the ridge on the east side of Electric Lake. There are some small pockets of private land that are posted well but the majority of the acreage is Forest Service. Much of this ridge burned in the Seeley Wildfire in 2012 which has improved the elk habitat in this area. Gentry Mountain. This is accessed from SR-10 just north of the town of Huntington at Huntington Reservoir. Part of this mountain is privately owned and part of it burned in the Seeley Wildfire in 2012 Ford Ridge (Late Rifle Hunters Only) This area is the top of a steep canyon overlooking Spring Canyon west of Helper. It holds bachelor groups of bulls in the fall and winter. There are numerous private lands around so be very careful of where you are. There is ample public lands also. West of Skyline

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This unit is currently over the population objective. Land Ownership on the unit is 89% Private Property-11% Public Land –Mostly US Forest Service. Written permission is required to hunt private property.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Hunters are reminded that bears often frequent the area. Campers and hikers should maintain a bear-safe campsite and dispose of trash properly. Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers. Meat and garbage should be stored inside a vehicle or hung in a tree at least 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, snow, wind and heat.  Be very cautious of lightning while hunting on high ridges or exposed slopes.  Early fall snow storms occur occasionally in this area, making many of the roads impassable.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 8.8~3200~4400~~~~~~~292~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Most elk are scattered throughout higher elevations, in remote areas away from major roads and ATV trails. Hunters are encouraged to do their preseason scouting on the unit and get written permission from private landowners prior to applying for the hunt. The Whitney Reservoir area contains most of the public land on this unit.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This unit is not managed for trophy quality and does not have a large amount of elk.  However, several decent bulls have been taken over the last few years and this unit is starting to receive a little more pressure.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: This mountain is rugged and steep.  Be prepared for harsh terrain and unexpected weather.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather during this hunt is generally warm and may receive rain and thunderstorms.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 7.7~1600 (entire Fillmore unit)~1350 (entire Fillmore unit)~~~~~~~56~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Elk are generally found in the higher elevation areas during the hunt but may also be found in low elevations on parts of the unit.  Areas to look include the (south to north) Church Mountains, Whisky Creek, drainages that feed into Dry Creek and Oak Creek, Fool Creek Pass area, and Leamington Pass (along the Sevier River).  Be aware of private property in these areas, especially near the Fool Creek and Leamington areas.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Pahvant has many steep and rugged areas. There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them. There is a main road across the top of the mountain with few ATV trails. Most of the ATV trails will be found on the southern half of the unit. There are some ATV trails that start in low elevation areas and go part way up several canyons. Many of the canyons have hiking trails that can help in accessing areas away from main roads. The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: The main access roads and the road along the top see a lot of traffic during the hunting season from both hunters and recreationists. Be cautious of others on the road. There is not a lot of water on top so be prepared with plenty of water. After heavy rain storms, many places along the road on top get very slick and it can become very easy to slide off the road. There are many steep and rugged areas with no cell coverage. Cell coverage is good on top of the mountain, depending on carrier, but is spotty in the canyons. The bear population is not large but has been increasing. It is always a good idea to keep a clean camp and keep food inaccessible for bears.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Weather can change quickly and you may see some light rainstorms during this time. The temperatures during this hunt are warm and can be in the 80's.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 23.5~1600 (entire Fillmore unit)~1350 (entire Fillmore unit)~~~~~~~146~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: This is a great unit to hunt elk. There are many really nice bulls harvested off this mountain every year. This hunt takes in the beginning of the rut in September and can be a great time to locate and hunt elk. Water is limited on the mountain and finding water sources away from main roads can be a productive for finding elk. Elk can be found across the entire unit. Get out on ridges and glass into some of the deep canyons. Many canyons north of Chalk Creek are great places to locate bulls.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This is a small elk population of approximately 20-30 elk. The objective is zero elk on this unit. It is a very difficult and low success hunt.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Use common sense. Let others know where you will be hunting, camped, etc. Some have been stranded by flat tires, very muddy conditions, flash floods, etc. Carry chains, survival kit, etc. Most areas have poor cell phone coverage. Consider hand held radios and a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Be prepared for inclement weather, it can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Keep abreast of the weather forecast. Expect and prepare unfavorable weather conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 0~0~25~~~~~~~4~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: The elk on the Henry's are not often seen. Usually when they are found they are on the eastern and southern slopes of Mt. Pennell or on the Northern side of Mt. Hillers. Unless you know this herd or have a lot of time this is not an ideal hunt for young hunters expecting to see and harvest an elk.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This subunit is mainly a wintering ground for Colorado's unit 40 elk herd.  There won't be a lot of elk on the subunit during the early hunts, but there will be a few resident elk that stay on the subunit year round.  Make sure that you are in good physical condition and spend plenty of time scouting prior to your hunt. Portions of the unit are extremely steep. Cow calling or bugling can prove to be very valuable in locating elk during the early season hunts.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Flash floods and lightning strikes are very likely during inclement weather, make sure to watch the sky and plan accordingly.  Always let somebody know where you'll be, and when you expect to be back.  Cell phone service is somewhat limited throughout the unit.  Black bears are regularly seen on the La Sal unit.  Keep a clean camp and make sure to place all food and garbage in locations that bears cannot get into.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  Late summer and early fall monsoon storms occur regularly in this area.  Be prepared for dry or muddy conditions, as well as flash flooding in canyon bottoms.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 33.3~2500 (entire La Sal unit)~2100 (entire La Sal unit)~~~~~~~26~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: This unit is winter range for elk that summer in the Glade Park and Pinon Mesa areas (unit 40) of western Colorado. CDPW biologists estimate the population of unit 40 at 2500-3500 elk. The number of elk that winter in the Dolores Triangle unit is dependent upon winter severity. Winter population numbers have typically varied between 300 and 700 elk.

Scouting Tips: Start scouting in mid July. Many of the elk will be in Colorado during this hunt, but there will be some resident elk and scouting at this time will give you a chance to see the number of elk you can expect on your hunt. The subunit is not large. Spend some time before your hunt to learn the roads and access points

Behavior: As with most big game animals the early mornings and evenings are the best times to find elk. During this hunt, the bulls are generally found together in bachelor groups. Smaller bulls are typically found with cows.

Elk rut: There will typically be a little rutting activity starting the first part of September, with the peak of the rut being September 15th-the end of September. There will still be some rutting activity in October, but it will be winding down by then.

Recommended areas Dolores Triangle Subunit:
Steamboat Mesa- Habitat treatments and fire have occurred in the area, draws a decent number of elk to the area in winter, good place to glass.
Ryan Creek/Granite Creek- Rugged canyon rims, limited access, good place for bulls latter in the year.
Ryan Park- Great area for elk (cows and bulls), good road and many places to glass for game.
Little Dolores- Can hold large herds of elk, good place to glass, bulls and cows found latter in the year.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Comprised mostly of private lands.  Most of the access is non motorized. The hunt is usually best after storms.  The elk do get pushed onto private land when pressured.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Let people know where you are going.  There is spotty cell phone reception even though you are close to the front.  Most high spots will have coverage.  Always be prepared for the worst conditions.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for hot & dry, or rainy, lightening, and windy conditions.  Snow storms can occur during this hunt.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 9.1~3800~6700~~~~~~~236~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Comprised mostly of private lands.  Most of the access is non motorized. The hunt is usually best after storms.  The elk do get pushed onto private land when pressured.

huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat. It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon. Be very cautious of lightening while hunting on high ridges. Early fall snow storms occur regularly in this area. Most years the snow will melt off, within a day or two until through the first week on October.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 6.7~700~1100~~~~~~~64~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: There are more elk on the Anthro unit in the winter than there are in the summer and early fall. Many elk migrate from surrounding units to winter on the Anthro. Some elk come all the way from the Strawberry Reservoir area. The migration is typically elk coming from the West to winter further East. This migration can start as early as October, after the rut. There is, however, a fair amount of resident elk scattered across the entire unit, even on the desert parts on the East half of the unit.

Scouting Tips: Start scouting in late June early July. The unit is very large with elk scattered across most of it. Spend some time before your hunt to learn the roads and access points. There are many springs and guzzlers on the unit and these are typically the best places to find elk during the summer and fall.

Behavior: As with most big game animals the early mornings and evenings are the best times to find elk. This is when most rutting activity will take place as well. The elk on the Anthro unit tend to move off the tops of the mountains and ridges into the thicker pinyon/juniper areas during the rut.

Elk rut: There will typically be a little rutting activity starting the first part of September, with the peak of the rut being September 15th-the end of September. There will still be some rutting activity in October, but it will be winding down by then.

Recommended areas Anthro Unit from West to East:
Indian Canyon- can only hunt the East side of Highway 191. Not great during the early seasons, but can be a great place for the Late Any Weapon hunt. Steep hillsides, and big canyons. Great place to glass.
Cottonwood Ridge- difficult access, better on the late hunt, can find bulls near the Tribal boundary during summer. Sowers Canyon- good access, many large canyons to glass. During the earlier hunts the far South end of the Canyon is best. The entire canyon is good during the late hunt.
Wire Fence Ridge- plenty of road access. Large aspen stands near the top of the ridge, there are also several steep hillsides that have been burned and these areas are great during late summer and early fall. There are several springs on the far North end, lots of bulls here in the summer.
Nutters Ridge- Main road access for the Anthro Mountain portion of the unit. Very similar to Wire Fence, good aspen stands up high and several water troughs and springs. The far North end of this ridge is currently being drilled heavily for oil, avoid these areas.
Jeep Trail- good access, a few good aspen stands and burned areas. Several guzzlers on the far North end. Bulls will use the high elevation parts of this ridge in summer and will move to the lower, thicker, pinyon/junipers during the rut.
Alkaline/Choke Cherry area- Really open area up high, several springs and guzzlers in this area as well. The open areas are used by bulls in the summer and then the bulls move to the lower thicker areas for the rut. Lots of road access on small secondary ridges.
Gilsonite Area- Lower elevation area. Lots of pinyon/juniper and sage brush draws. There are several guzzlers in this area. Most of

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This unit is a popular unit for general season hunters. It is also a general season unit for buck deer and is a popular tourist and fishing destination. Elk can be found throughout much of the unit during the any weapon hunt. Antlerless control permits are not valid on this unit. Habitat consists of pine, aspen, sagebrush, and some agricultural lands in the lower elevations.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Cellular phone coverage is spotty on this hunt unit. Satellite phones do work in the area. A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to drive to reach service. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

Camps should be kept clean to prevent bear incidents. Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers. Coolers are not bear-proof. Bears have gotten into camps in the past. Number and severity of bear incidents differ by year depending on weather and other food availability. Meat and garbage should be put away inside a vehicle or hung in a tree above 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically between the hunting seasons.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, snow, wind and heat.  It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon.  Be very cautious of lightning while hunting on high ridges or exposed slopes.  It is typically warm during the archery hunt, but early season snow can fall in the higher elevations.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 10.4 (Summit), 14.4 (West Daggett)~300 Summit, 1300 West Daggett~750 Summit, 1300 West Daggett~~~~~~~1074 (Summit), 447 (West Daggett)~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns:
Elk in this unit move back and forth across Wyoming and Utah state lines. The majority of the elk are up high in elevation during the summer and archery season and will move down in elevation towards Wyoming or Flaming Gorge Reservoir during the winter.

Scouting Tips:
In warm weather, hunters do best hunting water sources in mornings and evenings. Later in the season when there’s usually more water available, hunters do best either glassing for elk and then working to get close for a shot or stalking elk through the trees. Visibility on this unit is low due to dense trees. Elk are most active in the early mornings and late afternoons, which are the best times for scouting elk prior to and during the hunts.

Elk rut:
The elk rut usually runs from mid-September to early October and is usually starting towards the end of the archery season.

Where to find elk:
Elk are found throughout much of the unit. There are water sources across the unit in the form of stock ponds, creeks, and springs. In warm and dry weather, elk can be found close to these water sources.

Recommended areas in the North Slope, West Daggett:
Good areas to look for elk include along Hwy 44, Deep Creek, and along the road to Spirit Lake.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Low elk numbers. It can be tough to find elk at times. You will need to cover a lot of country to harvest an elk. Elk are scattered out across the entire unit during all of the hunting seasons making it even harder to locate them.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 0~140~200~~~~~~~26~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Elk often migrate from the lower elevations in the late fall and winter months to the higher elevations for the summer and early fall. However elk could be found across the unit at anytime during the year. This can make it tough because we do not have large numbers of elk on this unit. To be successful on this hunt you will need to put some time in scouting the unit, and trying to pattern the elk. A lot of the elk live in Bryce Canyon National Park during the hunting season so hunting the park boundary can be successful, but please know that you cannot kill or retrieve an animal harvested within the park boundary.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Fish Lake unit has a strong population objective of 5,600 elk and is a popular unit to hunt spike elk.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for hot & dry, or rainy, lightening, windy or even snowy conditions.  Early snow storms sometimes occur during this hunt.  Most of the time snow will melt off within a day or so.  Be prepared for muddy or snowy road conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 18.9 (Fishlake), 0.0 (Thousand Lakes)~5000 - 5900~5450~~~~~~~477 (Fishlake), 9 (Thousand Lakes)~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
The Fish Lake/Thousand Lakes unit is a great place to hunt spike elk. The unit has a strong population of elk with ample public land and access to it. Expect relatively high hunter numbers on opening weekend.

Elk will be spread across the entire unit during this hunt, though most will be above 8,000 ft. The highest concentration of elk will be in the center portion of the unit. After opening day the elk will seek refuge in deeper canyons and dense cover, especially conifers. During the middle of the week the herds tend to relax a little and feed out into the open.
Private property: There are four large ranches enrolled in the CWMU program on this unit. The elk seem to know where they are safe and many seek refuge on this private ground. This frustrates some hunters. There are still plenty of elk on the public land. Successful hunters need to be willing to hike a little farther to get away from the roads and trails to find elk.

The Thousand Lakes part of the unit has some resident elk that live there year-round but not very many. During this hunt don't expect to see a lot of elk here. Large numbers of elk tend to move there from the Fish Lake side once winter snows deepen.
The archery hunt often has high temperatures. Elk don't like the heat and will stick close to water sources and shady cover. Be prepared to cool meat quickly after a harvest to avoid spoilage.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This is one of the best elk units in the state, although it can be a tough hunt. Make sure that you are in good physical condition and spend plenty of time scouting prior to your hunt. Portions of the unit are extremely thick with vegetative cover and visibility is low. Cow calling or bugling can prove to be very valuable in locating elk during the early season hunts.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Flash floods and lightning strikes are very likely during inclement weather, make sure to watch the sky and plan accordingly. Always let somebody know where you'll be, and when you expect to be back. Cell phone service is somewhat limited throughout the unit. Black bears are regularly seen on the San Juan unit. Keep a clean camp and make sure to place all food and garbage in locations that bears cannot get into.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat. It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon. Be very cautious of lightening while hunting on high ridges and flash floods in the canyon bottoms.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 13.2~1300 (entire San Juan unit)~1400 (entire San Juan unit)~~~~~~~163~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: The elk on the San Juan limited entry unit typically migrate from West to East. Many of the bulls will start this migration after the rut ends in early October. The majority of the elk will winter on or near Dry Mesa, Salt Creek Mesa and Bridger Jack Mesa. Elk also migrate off of the high mesa tops, into lower elevation valleys throughout the unit.

Scouting Tips: Start scouting in late June early July. The unit is very large with elk scattered across most of it. Spend some time before your hunt to learn the roads, access points and watering holes.

Behavior: As with most big game animals the early mornings and evenings are the best times to find elk. This is when most rutting activity will take place as well. Typically spike bulls will be found with cows during this hunt.

Elk rut: There will typically be a little rutting activity starting the first part of September, with the peak of the rut being September 15th-the end of September. There will still be some rutting activity in October, but it will be winding down by then.

Recommended areas for the San Juan limited entry subunit:
Abajo Mountain- Higher elevations include large alpine meadows with aspen/conifer stands surrounding, lower elevations contain oak stands with large sagebrush clearings, good camping, nice roads, holds a good number of elk.
North Elk Ridge- A good area for elk, timbered North slopes, aspen stands, limited clearings for glassing, camping, nice roads, several different draws, canyons and mesa tops to hunt.
South Elk Ridge- Good roads on mesa tops, limited access to rugged canyons, great area for pack-in hunts (Dark Canyon).

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: During the hunts most of the elk on the subunit are found in canyon bottoms during the day.  The canyons contain pinyon/juniper habitats, and can be rugged with limited access.  I would recommend trying to locate remote watering holes or wallows, as well as locating the bulls on their way to and from the mesa tops just before sunrise and sunset. Permits are available over the counter, first come first serve.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Flash floods and lightning strikes are very likely during inclement weather, make sure to watch the sky and plan accordingly.  Always let somebody know where you'll be, and when you expect to be back.  Cell phone service is somewhat limited throughout the unit.  Black bears are regularly seen on the San Juan unit.  Keep a clean camp and make sure to place all food and garbage in locations that bears cannot get into.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  Late summer and early fall monsoon storms occur regularly in this area.  Be prepared for dry or muddy conditions, as well as flash flooding in canyon bottoms.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 16.7~1300 (entire San Juan unit)~1400 (entire San Juan unit)~~~~~~~52~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
General Considerations: This subunit is a General Season hunt unit and is not managed to be a trophy unit, but every year a few nice bulls are taken. Hunters should be aware of the private lands and learn the boundaries.

Migration Patterns: Elk on this subunit will migrate between the Utah and Colorado border, usually wintering on the Colorado side. There are some year round, resident elk that stay in the canyon bottoms during the day, and then feed on the mesa tops during the night.

Elk Rut: The elk rut usually runs from mid-September to mid-October.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This is a small elk population of approximately 20-40 resident elk that use Cedar Mountain plus some occasional winter migrating elk along the west benches of the Coal Cliffs South of I-70 and East of SR-10. The unit has an objective of zero elk. It is a difficult hunt with very low success.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Use common sense. Let others know where you will be hunting, camped, etc. Some have been stranded by flat tires, very muddy conditions, flash floods, etc. Carry chains, survival kit, etc. Many areas have fair cell phone coverage but not all. Consider hand held radios and a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Be prepared for inclement weather, it can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Keep abreast of the weather forecast. Expect and prepare unfavorable weather conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 0.0 (entire San Rafael unit)~0 (entire San Rafael unit)~—~~~~~~~34 (entire San Rafael unit)~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Pre-season, the Cedar Mtn elk sometimes use the desert shrub hills between Cedar Mountain and the farmlands east of the town of Lawrence. Other times they will use the Pinion-Juniper slopes of Cedar Mountian and are difficult to locate. If you see tracks you might be able to track them. A small number of Fishlake elk will sometimes cross I-70 during the winter and go onto the benches west of the Coal Cliffs. Sometimes elk from the Manti also winter in the Coal Cliffs area, but generally these are low in number as well. Unless you know this herd or have a lot of time this is not an ideal hunt for young hunters expecting to see and harvest an elk.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: About 60% of the Wasatch unit is pubic land the other 40% is private. Watch for posted lands.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
Camps should be kept clean to prevent bear incidents.  Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Rains can make the roads slick.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 61.4 (West), 6.4 (Currant Creek), 5.7 (Avintaquin)~1800 Avintaquin, 3200 Currant Creek, 3400 West~2600 Avintaquin, 4000 Currant Creek, 3500 West~~~~~~~1066 (West), 537 (Currant Creek), 228 (Avintaquin)~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Recommended area on Wasatch West subunit: Strawberry Reservoir-All canyons around the reservoir have elk in them. Try Clyde Creek, Squaw Creek, Horse Creek, Indian Canyon, Chipman Creek, Poison Ridge, French Hollow, Buffalo Canyon, and Willow Creek. Strawberry Ridge- The ridge road is rough, in some places on ATV have access. This is a great place to glass and listen for elk. Sheep Creek: Try hunting the Waters along the Rays Valley road. Each of the Waters (first through sixth) has a trail head. Try hunting Halls Fork and Yellow Jacket areas. Diamond Fork/Hobble Creek- Try hunting the upper sections, elk will move into the lower sections later in the season. Mt. Timpanogos- There is a herd of around 200 elk in this area. Try looking around Cascade Springs, the top of American Fork Canyon, and the west side above Grove and Battle Creek.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
Most hunters plan on spending at least 3-4 days hunting. There are few water sources so plan on bringing extra water in with you. Foot hunters who plan to hunt in the upper elevations should plan on staying up there for several days. It is just too far to come down every day. I would plan on a very challenging and rewarding hunt. Review your maps frequently to avoid trespass issues on the Goshute Tribal Land.

This area is patrolled quite frequently by DWR and BLM personnel. Keep this in mind when you are transporting your game and driving an ATV. Try to make it easy to access the permit and tag on the animal.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
This is a very remote location with limited access. Cellular phones will not work. Digital cell phones may show a bar but will not connect due to the distance to the cell towers. Satellite phones do work in the area. The Biologist suggests handheld radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return. Bring an extra spare tire, water and gas. There are not facilities. Wendover is the closest (60 miles).

It is not uncommon to have thunderstorms, flash floods and have trails wash out. If it rains hard it makes it difficult to navigate the trails.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat. Thunder storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region. Most hunters struggle with meat spoiling in the heat. I would plan on hot weather and plan accordingly.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 0~350 (entire West Desert unit)~200 (entire West Desert unit)~~~~~~~34~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest: Most of the harvest is from the bench above Ibapah. In recent years elk behavior has changed a little bit. Some of the elk have moved out to the flats west of Ibapah. Caution should be taken when hunting west of Ibapah. The Goshute Reservation Lands are not open to hunting and all fence lines look alike. Consult the the Goshutes for the latest map.

Elk are found top to bottom. Most archery hunters have the most success early in the hunt sitting on remote water holes. As the hunt progress the elk start to rut and become easier to spot and stalk.

Migration Patterns: During the archery hunt I would expect to see herds of cows, calves, and spike bulls. The bulls will start breaking up from their bachelor herds. If there isn’t much pressure in the bottom of the canyons I would expect to see elk coming out in the evenings to drink from the creeks and springs. You may find elk centralized from Cold Springs to the Delle.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Comprised mostly of private lands.  Most of the access is non motorized. The hunt is usually best after storms.  The elk do get pushed onto private land when pressured.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Comprised mostly of private lands.  Most of the access is non motorized. The hunt is usually best after storms.  The elk do get pushed onto private land when pressured.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for hot & dry, or rainy, lightening, and windy conditions.  Snow storms can occur during this hunt.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 20.5~1800~3000~~~~~~~189~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Comprised mostly of private lands.  Most of the access is non motorized. The hunt is usually best after storms.  The elk do get pushed onto private land when pressured.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This is a high plateau with steep canyons dissecting it.  Most of the elk reside at high elevations during the archery hunt.  The vast majority of the high elevation habitat is privately owned and managed under the CWMU program.  Study a map thoroughly prior to hunting this unit, and bring a gps unit.  It can be very tricky staying on public land
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: There is poor cell coverage.  There are steep canyons.  There are very few sources of water.  The Bruin Point Dugway is very steep.  Be very careful pulling a trailer up the dugway if at all.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Generally it is still  mighty warm during the archery hunt.  Expect warm days with cool nights with frequent monsoon rainstorms
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 8.3~1800~2100~~~~~~~103~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Public land hunting opportunities for archery elk are limited.  The Cold Springs WMA just east of Bruin Point is a good area.  Most of this WMA is walk in access only.  There is good water in this area.  There is typically less than 50 elk residing in this area.  There is a small block of public lands on Patmos Ridge just south of Bruin Point near the headwaters of Range Creek.  These are the two largest blocks of public lands and they are both less than 3000 acres of good elk habitat.  Occasionally hunters will find elk on the public land near Tidwell Spring on Cottonwood Ridge near the private land boundary.  Hunt success on this unit is very low primarily due to the fact that 80 to 90% of the elk reside on private land this time of year.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Let people know where you are going.  There is spotty cell phone reception even though you are close to the front.  Most high spots will have coverage.  Always be prepared for the worst conditions.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Let people know where you are going.  There is spotty cell phone reception even though you are close to the front.  Most high spots will have coverage.  Always be prepared for the worst conditions.
