huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Let people know where you are going.  There is spotty cell phone reception even though you are close to the front.  Most high spots will have coverage.  Always be prepared for the worst conditions.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This hunt is not managed for trophy quality, yet each year many nice bulls are taken. Scouting is extremely important in order to harvest an elk. A lot of areas on the unit with very steep and rocky terrain.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Cellular phone coverage is spotty on this hunt unit.  Satellite phones do work in the area. 
Hunters are reminded that bears often frequent the area. Campers and hikers should maintain a bear-safe campsite and dispose of trash properly. Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers. Meat and garbage should stored inside a vehicle or hung in a tree at least 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree. Written permission is required to hunt private property.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Weather conditions vary, be prepared for winter weather with possible snow and cold temps. Winter weather conditions will make many of the roads and trails impassable.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 3.7~850~1050~~~~~~~348~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Most elk are scattered throughout higher elevations, in remote areas away from major roads and ATV trails. Hunters are encouraged to do their preseason scouting on the unit. Weather conditions dramatically affect will elk will be found during the hunting season.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This is a great unit for the opportunity to harvest an elk . Make sure that you are in good physical condition and spend plenty of time scouting prior to your hunt. Portions of the unit are extremely steep. Cow calling or bugling can prove to be very valuable in locating elk during the early season hunts.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Flash floods and lightning strikes are very likely during inclement weather, make sure to watch the sky and plan accordingly.  Always let somebody know where you'll be, and when you expect to be back.  Cell phone service is somewhat limited throughout the unit.  Black bears are regularly seen on the La Sal unit.  Keep a clean camp and make sure to place all food and garbage in locations that bears cannot get into.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  Late summer and early fall monsoon storms occur regularly in this area.  Be prepared for dry or muddy conditions, as well as flash flooding in canyon bottoms.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 9.7~2500 (entire La Sal unit)~2100 (entire La Sal unit)~~~~~~~309~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: The elk on the La Sal Mountains typically migrate from West to East. Many of the bulls will start this migration after the rut ends in early October. The majority of the elk will winter on or near the JB Ranch CWMU, or near the Utah/Colorado border. Elk also migrate off of the high mesa tops, into lower elevation valleys throughout the unit.

Scouting Tips: Start scouting in late June early July. The unit is very large with elk scattered across most of it. Spend some time before your hunt to learn the roads and access points

Behavior: As with most big game animals the early mornings and evenings are the best times to find elk. This is when most rutting activity will take place as well. Spike bulls will be found with cows during this hunt.

Elk rut: There will typically be a little rutting activity starting the first part of September, with the peak of the rut being September 15th-the end of September. There will still be some rutting activity in October, but it will be winding down by then.

Recommended areas La Sal Mountains Subunit: Bar-A Creek- Northeast side of the mountain, large meadows with aspen stands mixed with conifers, great camping, nice roads, holds a good number of elk.
Pine Ridge- This entire area is good for elk, timbered North slopes, aspen stands, great access, camping, nice roads, several different draws or canyons to hunt.
Deep Creek- No roads and limited access, great area for pack-in hunts, borders private lands in many spots, great area for elk.
Dark Canyon- Higher elevation, borders some private lands, one good main road with several two-track roads splitting off, great camping, good place to glass for elk on the early season hunts.
La Sal Pass- Lots of places to glass for elk, rolling meadows with timbered North facing slopes and large aspen stands, not a lot of cows, but does hold a good number of bulls.
North/South/Polar Mesas- These mesas are typically best for the late hunts, great for ATV’s, good place for late season hunts.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Most elk are south of State Route 21 which bisects the unit east to west.  There are a some elk north of 21 but most are south.  Elk are found on all mountain ranges except for the Black Hills between Cedar City and Minersville.  Elk use all habitats from the bottom of the valleys to the top of the mountains.  The Southwest Desert Unit is 96% public land, but hunters should be aware of the private lands and learn the boundaries.  Please be respectful of private lands and other hunters.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Hunters should be prepared with extra gas and water this unit is remote and there are no services available.  This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access.  Cellular phone coverage is very spotty on this hunt unit.  Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers.  Satellite phones do work in the area.  The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Expect warm and dry conditions though out most seasons on this unit.  The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  Usually warm temperatures and monsoonal moisture dominate the weather pattern. Be prepared for dry or muddy conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 9.3~975~975~~~~~~~185~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Spike bulls can be found throughout the unit. More elk reside in the central portions of the unit on and surrounding the Indian Peaks Range. Elk can be found from the bottoms of the valleys in the open sagebrush to the top of the mountain in the Pinions and Mahogany.  The Southwest Desert unit is a very large unit. It can be a difficult hunt. You may have days without seeing an elk because the density is low.  To increase your chances of seeing elk it is best to find water in good elk habitat.  There are several guzzlers and springs in this desert area, but even around these water sources there are very few elk. Some good areas to hunt are the following: 

Stateline/Hamlin Valley – BLM and SITLA lands along the Utah/Nevada border from the Paradise to White Rocks areas. This area is very accessible with some larger blocks of private properties.

Indian Peaks Range –  BLM, SITLA and DWR lands from Arrowhead Pass to Vance Pass.  This area also has a few larger blocks of private land.  

South Wah Wah Range- BLM and SITLA lands from Rose Spring Canyon to Highway 21 on Wah Wah summit.  This area is covered heavily with pinion and juniper.  Hunting near perennial water sources will greatly increase your success. 

Mountain Home Range- BLM and SITLA lands from the Loper’s Reseed area to Mt Home Pass. This area is covered heavily with pinion and juniper.  Hunting near perennial water sources will greatly increase your success. 

Jockeys and Shaunties –BLM and SITLA lands located west of Minersville SW of Milford.  This area is closer to human population centers and may have higher hunter densities.

huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 17.9~1000 - 1400~1100~~~~~~~408~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Elk numbers during summer months aren't as high as they are during the winter months on this unit. Alot of the elk migrate off of the unit for the summer months and return during the fall and winter months. This can be a tough hunt, but mature bulls are harvested on it every year.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: A lot of roadless areas on the unit expect backcountry hunting conditions.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Summer months are generally warm, but afternoon thunderstorms can be present most days in the afternoon.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 0~1500 - 2000~1400~~~~~~~39~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: This unit has several areas that have no vehicle access. Hunters that hike into some of these areas, or use horses have good success at harvesting elk. Before snow falls on the unit you can access the top of the mountain from Antimony, or Cottonwood Creek in Johns Valley. Elk in the summer can be found across the unit in higher and lower elevations. There is good access on most of the BLM lands across the unit, but a lot of the forest service has limited access. There is good access on the south end of the unit in the Hunt Creeks, and often holds elk year round. There was a large fire that burned on the unit in 2002. This made it very good for glassing long distances. There is a lot of pinon and juniper in the lower elevations with Aspen, and mixed conifer stands at higher elevations. During summer months find water and hunt areas around it. A lot of the elk can be found at higher elevations during this hunt.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Panguitch Lake elk herd is currently managed for 1,100 wintering elk across the unit. Recent surveys and estimates suggest the population is approximately 1,700. Substantial summer range exists on the Markagunt Plateau which is heavily forested. There are also several mid-elevation areas across the unit that bull elk will use as summer range. Elk occupy most all suitable habitat throughout the unit and begin migratory movements towards the beginning of October which is likely dependent on weather patterns.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: The Panguitch Lake unit offers substantial truck and ATV access. Cellular phone coverage within this hunt boundary is generally good but there are areas within the hunt boundary with little or no coverage. The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return. Plan on bringing plenty of water, fuel, good tires with extra spares, and plenty of ice.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for rain, lightning, as well as warm weather conditions. Storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 10.2~1100 - 1300~840~~~~~~~378~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest: Large nursery groups of cow elk can be observed generally very early in the morning or right before sunset. During warmer times of the day, elk will be staying cool in the forested areas and will be more difficult to observe. Focus on areas with high densities of aspen near water sources.

Migration Patterns: All elk in this hunt boundary will migrate but these movements are generally not observed until late September and October. Migration from summer ranges may be dependent on fall storms and weather conditions.

Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars will be helpful. Scouting is most effective right before the hunt opens. I would plan on covering a lot of ground to locate public lands and access points and hiking trails.

Behavior: Elk will be on summer range with younger calves and will not likely be begin the rut until later in the month and in Sept. Some of the nursery groups may be found in large groups but smaller groups of elk are possible.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Zion elk herd is currently managed for 300 wintering elk across the unit.  Recent surveys and estimates suggest the population is approximately 350. There is substantial interchange of elk from the Panguitch Lake unit from the north during the summer months which may inflate summering elk numbers.  Access to private lands and hunting restrictions in Zion National Park can reduce harvest success and make this a challenging hunt.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
The Zion unit offers substantial truck and ATV access.  Cellular phone coverage within this hunt boundary is spotty and there are areas within the hunt boundary with little or no coverage.  

The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
Plan on bringing plenty of water, fuel, good tires with extra spares, and plenty of ice.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Storms can cause muddy road conditions and/or be impassible with high snow conditions
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 4.2~300~800~~~~~~~408~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: Migratory movements generally begin in late September and October. Migration from summer ranges may be dependent on fall storms and weather conditions.

Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars will be helpful. Scouting is most effective right before the hunt opens. I would plan on covering a lot of ground to locate public lands and access points and hiking trails.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Pine Valley elk population is very small.  The population objective is 50 and it is currently estimated to be around 75.  Elk are a rare sight on this unit.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Weather in the early portion of the season is very warm. In the November/December portion of the season day time temps area into the 50-60's and night time temps are below freezing.  Expect some rain and snow.  Snow does not usually last for for more than a couple of days.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 10~50~50~~~~~~~86~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: A few elk can be found north of Atchison Peak and west of Harrison Peak in the Horse Valley area.  The majority of the elk area found in the area west of enterprise along the the state line from Pine Park then north up to the Crest line and the Nephi Spring area. This portion of the population is transient between Utah and Nevada. In recent years a few elk have been found north of Pinto and in the Silver Peak/Antelope Peak areas.  When Hunting in the Pine Park and Crestline areas be sure to know where the state line is at all times.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Elk densities on the unit are usually low, and at times during the year it is possible that no elk will be on the unit at all.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Monitor local weather forecasts and plan accordingly.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 8.0 (entire Cache unit)~2300 (entire Cache unit)~3350 (entire Cache unit)~~~~~~~644 (entire Cache unit)~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Elk come onto the unit from time to time and can be found on the higher elevations of the Crawford Mountains in August and September, and on the East Side of Bear Lake near the Idaho border.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Elk are not a common sight across most of this unit and the harvest rate is low. Spending time scouting for elk will be critical to be successful.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Cell coverage is okay in much of the unit but spotty in some areas.  Roads can become very slippery after storms.  Be aware of your surroundings and other people as some of the main roads receive a fair amount of use.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Weather conditions are warm but can vary dramatically during this hunt.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 3~1050 (entire Beaver unit)~850 (entire Beaver unit)~~~~~~~142~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: The elk populations on this unit is kept very low.  Areas that may hold elk include areas just west of the Sulpherdale exit on I-15 (just south of the I-15/I-70 interchange), and the hills just north of the Black Rock road.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
This unit is a General Season hunt unit and is not managed to be a trophy unit but every year a few really nice bulls are taken. Hunters should be aware of the Ute Tribal Lands and learn the boundaries. Public hunting is not permitted on Tribal Lands. There are no CWMUs on this unit.

The unit includes much of the High Uintas Wilderness area. The Wilderness can provide a remote hunt with few hunters but elk can be hard to locate. Much of the habitat in the high country is fairly sterile without much feed for elk. It is generally Lodge Pole Pine without much of an understory. In the Wilderness elk are usually found either above tree line in or in the "parks" or meadows in the conifer belt or along the base of the "bollies" where there is usually a strip of green grass and water.

Road access on the remainder of the unit is limited to mostly canyon bottoms due to the steepness of the terrain. Most of the elk during this hunt are found outside the wilderness boundary.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Cellular phone coverage can be spotty in some parts of this hunt unit.  Satellite phones or a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to drive to reach service.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
Camps should be kept clean to prevent bear incidents.  Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers.  Coolers are not bear-proof.  Bears have gotten into camps in the past.  Number and severity of bear incidents differ by year depending on weather and other food availability.  Meat and garbage should be put away inside a vehicle or hung in a tree above 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for hot & dry, or rainy, lightening, windy or even snowy conditions.  Early snow storms occur often during this hunt.  Most of the time snow will melt off within a day or so.  Be prepared for muddy or snowy road conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 10.3 (Bonanza), 10.2 (Vernal), 9.8 (Yellowstone)~3000 (Bonanza/Diamond Mtn/Vernal subunits), 5000 Yellowstone~3800 (Bonanza/Diamond Mtn/Vernal subunits), 7400 Yellowstone~~~~~~~249 (Bonanza), 717 (Vernal), 833 (Yellowstone)~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: During this hunt it is not uncommon to find bulls right at timberline. Elk on this unit move down in elevation for the winter and they winter primarily on Ute Tribal lands and private phosphate mine property or on south facing slopes at lower elevation on the Forest Service lands. The elk usually start to move towards the Tribal Land or Phosphate mine boundary as soon as they get much hunting pressure. There is very little hunting pressure on the Tribal Lands or on the phosphate mine so elk have learned to go there as soon as hunting pressure starts. Hunting near the Tribal & phosphate mine boundary can be productive in a lot of areas.

Elk rut: The elk rut on this unit usually peaks around mid to late Sept.. This year this hunt will run later into the rut which should increase hunter success. The later into this hunt you go the more rutty the elk will likely become.

Recommended areas in the South Slope, Yellowstone:
There are numerous suggested areas to hunt on this unit.

The Wilderness Area can provide a remote hunt with few hunters but is a very tough area to hunt and it can be hard to locate elk. Much of the habitat in the high country is fairly sterile without much feed for elk. It is generally Lodge Pole Pine without much of an understory. Elk in the Wilderness are generally found above tree line or in small pockets of openings in the lodge pole cover. The larger openings are called parks and can be found on most maps but the smaller openings are scattered across the high country. As stated above, often elk can be found in the high country along the base of the "bollies" where the rocky cliffs meet the timber. There is usually a narrow strip of grass and often water springs along this strip and elk utilize those areas. If you choose to hunt the high country, be prepared for unpredictable weather and lots of rocks.

During the hunts most of the deer & elk on the unit are found in the habitat belt where aspen mixes with sagebrush and conifer. That zone across the South Slope is the most productive for big game. Every canyon across the South Slope, Yellowstone has elk and they are of similar quality.

The suggested areas to hunt include (starting on the west side of the unit):
Soapstone area - high elevation, but more road access, closer to the Wasatch Front.
North Fork of the Duchesne- limited road access
Blind Stream - limited road access, tribal land down low, popular area
Log Hollow- must cross Tribal Lands to access, rough roads
Rock Creek - paved road access, steep areas
Pigeon Water - popular area but hunters must be aware of tribal boundary
Bear Wallow - hunters must be aware of tribal boundary, steep terrain
Lake Fork/Moon Lake- paved road access, some private property along the paved road
Yellowstone - rough roads, need to be aware of Tribal boundary
77 Flat/Burnt Mill- gravel roads, a little flatter area, be aware of Tribal boundary
Dry Gulch- very rough road, steep terrain, be aware of Tribal boundary on the east
Uinta Canyon- Tribal lands down low, steep Terrain
Elk Horn Loop - gravel roads that go almost to the summit of the Uintas, lots of opportunity to scatter out
Whiterocks Canyon - Whiterocks river is the eastern subunit boundary, steep terrain

Recommended areas in the South Slope, Vernal:
There are numerous suggested areas to hunt on this unit.

There is a variety of habitat to hunt during the any weapon hunt. There is pinyon/juniper, sage brush savanna, thick lodge pole pine, and areas above timber line. The larger openings on the forest are called parks and can be found on most maps but the smaller openings are scattered across the high country. If you choose to hunt the high country, be prepared for unpredictable weather and rocky terrain.

During the hunts most of the elk on the unit are found in the habitat belt where aspen mixes with conifer. I would recommend trying to locate remote watering holes or wallows, and hunt feeding areas.

The suggested areas to hunt include (starting on the west side of the unit):
Whiterocks Canyon – Whiterocks River is the western subunit boundary, steep terrain
Paradise Park-Higher forest terrain, steep forested canyons
Mosby Mountain-High aspen forest, with large sagebrush bowls, excellent habitat
Red Cloud Loop Rd-Long road that starts in Dry Fork Canyon (west of Vernal). It takes you all the way through the Vernal unit, and comes out on Hwy 191.
Taylor Mountain-Great vantage points. Excellent area to glass and locate animals from far distances.
Colton Ranger Station-Aspen/conifer mix forest
Lime Stone, Little V, and Range Study-These areas are east of Hwy 191 and border a limited elk unit (Diamond Mountain).

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Beaver offers a challenging landscape. There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them. A lot of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access. There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads. The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 6.1~1050 (entire Beaver unit)~850 (entire Beaver unit)~~~~~~~211~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest: The majority of hunters choose to hunt the higher elevation areas during the archery hunt. The areas around Big Johns flat and Big Flat hold large amounts of elk. There are canyons and areas surrounding those areas where you can get out and hike to get away from people. There is plenty of water on the mountain for the elk. However as you hike you can find several unmarked springs. The northern areas of the unit have recently been through an extensive burn. As the burned area reestablishes vegetation it attracts large amounts of elk.

Migration Patterns: You will find elk from one end of the Beaver to the other. The elk will start feeling pressured toward the end of the archery hunt with increased rifle hunters scouting for their upcoming hunt. During the winter months the bulls prefer to stay in the highest elevations. They will locate wind swept south slopes and wait out the winter. The cows and calves will migrate to lower elevations. After the calving season you can find large herds of elk at higher elevation in grassy meadows. Once the rut begins the bulls begin to herd up smaller herds of cows and the elk seem to spread out through the whole Beaver Range.

Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential for scouting elk in this area. Scouting is most effective late-summer to early fall. If you are able to place trail cameras on the remote springs and water holes you will be able to pattern elk movements. In the hot early fall temperatures I would expect to see the most animals at prime time (1/2 hour before dawn and an hour before sunset). There are several recovering burned areas that have produced large amounts of grass that is excellent for elk. Elk spend a lot of time in the aspen patches where there is a good understory of grass and forbs. Scouting during the summer is effective for learning the areas where you want to hunt. I would not expect to see the same elk on the same ridge during the summer and also in the fall. The elk do tend to move before the rut. I would focus scouting efforts during the first of September.

Behavior: The elk seem to prefer bedding down in the dark conifer timber during the day. Towards the evening the elk will start to work their way onto the burned faces and points of the ridges. Once the bulls shed their velvet they will start to break up from their winter and summer bachelor herds. They will usually water at least two times a day. It is not unusual for elk to graze through the night. As the hunt progresses and if colder weather moves in, the elk will start to come into the rut. Before they start to herd the cows up the bulls are very susceptible to cow elk calls. I have had success calling bulls in from far distances in the unit with the use of a cow call in early September. As elk get closer to the rut they will become more vocal and will start to round up small herds of cows. The larger bulls will usually try to keep their cows away from contending bulls including spikes. It is normal to have one herd bull and other satellite and spike bulls surrounding the cows at a distance.

During this hunt it is effective to hunt water holes early on the hunt. Later in the hunt it is more efficient to call and locate the bulls and try to get them to come to cow calls.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This unit is mostly private lands.Access is very limited. Salt Lake county east of I-15 is archery only for bull elk.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: This unit is steep and rocky.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Late season rain and snow can make the ground and rock slick.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: ~~~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Elk numbers on this sub-unit is very low and hunter success is also low. Elk are found on the north end of the unit, in upper Lambs Canyon and Mill Creek Canyon.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: On extremely rare occasion a few elk have shown up along the Fremont River near the Cainville area. We believe they are coming from the Thousand Lakes herd.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 0.0 (entire San Rafael unit)~0 (entire San Rafael unit)~—~~~~~~~34 (entire San Rafael unit)~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: This unit is open for the rare occasion that when elk do come down along the Fremont River towards Cainville that hunters could harvest an elk. In 2014 there was a yearling cow grazing in hay fields along the river and most recently in May 2016 a handful of elk were spotted along the river near Cainville. We think that these elk did not return to the summer range on Thousand Lakes.

huntMaster.SPECIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: If you obtain this permit you may hunt on any unit designated "Spike Only" or "Any Bull Elk" but may only take the appropriate type on a unit and only with archery equipment
huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Voluntary: The DWR conducts random surveys for all general season hunts. You may be contacted via phone to participate in this survey.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by SITLA and DWR. There is a large DWR Wildlife Management Area (WMA) known as the Little Creek WMA. This area is managed for wildlife and the DWR encourages hunting on all WMA’s.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads. 
DWR WMA’S: UDWR WMAs is limited to 14 days at one location.  
There are no established campgrounds in this unit, it is a first-come first-served basis.  Some hunters prefer to camp at the trailheads.  There are DWR cabins in this unit that are not for public use.  There is no camping allowed within a quarter mile of a DWR cabin.  

The trails are seasonally maintained by the DWR, and sportsmen.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
There are two trailheads for the roadless area, a north and a south.  The north access is called the Ten Mile Knoll trailhead.   If you take Utah State Road 88, it is located between Vernal and Roosevelt.  Follow SR 88 south and it turns into the Seep Ridge Road.  The Seep Ridge Rd splits and becomes the Divide Rd.  If you take the Divide Rd west the trail head is at the start of Steer Ridge.  There is a sign at the parking area.  It is a large parking area but it can fill up in a hurry with trucks and horse trailers.  The Hay Canyon Rd is the main access road on the south side of the Book Cliffs.  You can access it from I-70.  It is a hard packed dirt/gravel road.  The Steer Ridge Rd can be very dangerous if it has been snowing or raining but it can dry out quickly.

The south trail head starts at the top of Sego Canyon.  The road starts at Thompson Springs in Grand County and continues up the Sego Canyon Rd; follow it to the end of the road.  There is a water trough at the trailhead but it is not always full of water.  This trailhead can also fill up with vehicles and trailers.  There are no bathrooms or other facilities at either of these trailheads, so plan accordingly.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs, and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: N/A
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
This area has strict travel constraints.  It is limited to horse and foot travel.  Sportsmen should take this into account before they put in for this unit.  The Steer Ridge Rd is one road that borders the northeast boundary of the unit.  There are no other roads around this unit.   

The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape.  There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The Ute Tribe as agreed to allow sportsmen to access this area across Ute Tribal trust lands.  Once you leave the Sego Trailhead parking area and start down the Went Ridge trail you are on Tribal land for the first few miles.  There are signs indicating that you have permission from the Tribe to use this route.  We ask that you please keep this area clean and stay on the main trail until you are off of Ute Tribal land.  This is a privilege and abuse of this area could lead to sportsmen losing this access permit.  This hunt excludes all Ute Tribal lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand County--Boundary begins at the Steer Ridge road at Ten Mile Knoll and the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide); southwest along the Book Cliffs summit on Diamond Ridge to the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation boundary (Hells Hole/head of Sego Canyon); north on this boundary (west side of West Willow Creek) to the DWR Wildlife Management Area/Ute Tribe Fence at the confluence of East and West Willow Creek; northeast from this confluence; cross-country to the Steer Ridge road (NW 1/4 Sec 7, T17S R21E); south and east on the Steer Ridge road (atop the drainage divide) to Ten Mile Knoll and the Book Cliffs summit. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Westwater. Boundary questions? Call Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

Box Elder and Weber counties—Boundary begins at 12th Street and I-15 in Ogden; north on I-15 to the Utah/Idaho state line; west on this state line to SR-42; southeast on SR-42 to SR-30; southwest on SR-30 to township line of R15W and R16W; due south on this line to Union Pacific railroad tracks; east on these tracks(causeway) to 12th Street; east on this street to I-15 in Ogden. This hunt is comprised of all or largely private property. Hunters should acquire written permission from the landowner before applying for this hunt. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Grouse Creek, Promontory Point, Tremonton. Boundary questions: Call Ogden office, 801-476-2740.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Land ownership is primarily private.  Landowners will allow access, but will charge trespass fees to hunt their property.  Be prepared to pay $5,000 to $8,000 dollars to access private property.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Not vary many camping areas are available on the unit, but camping on the adjacent South Cache unit is available. See the Logan Ranger District website for info on camping.
http://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/uwcnf/recreation/camping-cabins

huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV access is limited.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Mostly private land.  Obtain written permission to access private property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Rich County—Boundary begins at US-89 and the USFS boundary west of Garden City; south along this USFS boundary to SR-39; east on SR-39 to SR-16; north on SR-16 to SR-30; northwest on SR-30 to US-89; west on US-89 to the USFS boundary. Boundary questions? Call the Ogden office, 801-476-2740.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Most of the summer and fall elk habitat is on public lands managed by the Forest Service.  There are however large tracts of private lands on the northeast portion of the unit in the area surrounding Scofield Reservoir.  Late Season Rifle hunters will have a little more private land to deal with as bulls transition to lower elevations.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Gordon Creek, Lower Fish Creek, Starvation, Dairy Fork, Lake Fork, Birdseye, Lasson Draw, White Hill, Black Hill, Bald Mountain, Sixmile, Miller Manti Face, Nine Mile, Twelve Mile, Willow Creek.  Most of these properties are on winter range for elk.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service.  This unit is on the Manti La Sal National Forest.  Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service.  Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites at http://www.fs.usda.gov/mantilasal
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The Upper Fish Creek trailhead can be found on the west side of Scofield Reservoir.  It travels west to the opposite trailhead on Skyline Drive near Johnson Ridge
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: 1:100,000 USGS maps include;  Price, Nephi, Huntington, Manti, Salina
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service at http://www.fs.usda.gov/mantilasal

There are also several roads and ATV trails on land managed by the Utah Division of Wildlife Resources. All vehicles and ATV’s must stay on designated roads and trails on these lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: see above
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are no tribal lands to contend with. The vast majority of the early bull elk hunt habitat is on public land. A few exceptions include the following areas. The northeast portion of the mountain near Scofield Reservoir has a high percentage of private land on good elk habitat. Most of these lands are managed under the CWMU program and can not provide hunter access as your permit will not be valid on those properties. Other private properties require prior written permission before hunting. Small pockets of private lands at high elevations can be found surrounding Electric Lake and on East Mountain. Late Season any weapon hunters may encounter private lands in the Spring Canyon area west of Helper as well as upper Gordon Creek. Weather Conditions: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat. It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon. Be very cautious of lightening while hunting on high ridges. Early fall snow storms occur regularly in this area. Most years the snow will melt off, within a day or two until the first week of October.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Carbon, Emery, Sanpete, Sevier and Utah counties—Boundary begins at the junction of US-6 and US-89 in Spanish Fork Canyon; southeast on US-6 to Price and SR-10; south on SR-10 to I-70; west on I-70 to US-89; north on US-89 to US-6 in Spanish Fork Canyon. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Nephi, Price, Huntington, Manti, Salina. Boundary questions? Call the Springville office, 801-491-5678 or the Price office, 435-613-3700.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Mostly privately owned property.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Very limited, except in the Whitney reservoir area.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Chalk Creek road near Coalville, Utah. Highway 150 south of Evanston Wyoming.

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: mostly private property
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Primarily private land--Summit and Duchesne counties--Boundary begins at I-84 and I-80 near Echo; northeast on I-80 to the Utah-Wyoming state line; southeast along this state line to SR-150; south on SR-150 to Pass Lake and the Weber River trail; west on this trail to Holiday Park and CR 2596 (Weber Canyon road); west on this road to SR-32; northwest on SR-32 to I-80 at Wanship; north on I-80 to I-84 near Echo. This hunt is comprised of all or largely private property. Hunters should acquire written permission from the landowner before applying for this hunt. huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: BLM and Private
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Questions about camping and campgrounds can be answered at the Fillmore field offices of the BLM and USFS.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The black rock road on the south end as well as several roads between Kanosh and Holden.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: There are many roads throughout the unit that can be traveled on by a truck or ATV.  There are also many roads that require an ATV or are better traveled by an ATV.  Please stay on existing roads and trails.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are large tracts of private land across the unit.  There is also a CWMU within the boundaries of the unit that cannot be hunted on with this tag.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Juab and Millard counties--Boundary begins at  I-15 (Exit-207) and  the Mills road; west on this road to the railroad tracks; west on these tracks to the Sevier River; north along this river to SR-132; west on SR-132 to US-50; west on US-50 to SR-257; south on SR-257 to the Black Rock road; east on this road to I-15; north on I-15 to Exit 207 and the Mills road. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Delta, Lynndyl, Manti, Nephi, Richfield. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: There is some private land on the north end in Robins valley.  The larger tracts of private land are found on the south end of the Pahvant and along winter range.  See map for details.  There is plenty of public land with large numbers of deer available to hunt.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Established campgrounds are lower in elevation and can be found on the east side (Maple Grove) and on the west side (Maple Hollow - east of Holden; Meadow Creek - east of Meadow; Adelaide - East of Kanosh.  Many of these campgrounds are popular on weekends throughout the summer.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:

The larger tracts of private land are found on the south end of the Pahvant and along winter range.  There is some tribal land found down low near Kanosh.  See map for details.  There is plenty of public land with large numbers of deer available to hunt.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Millard and Sevier counties—Boundary begins at I-70 and I-15; north on I-15 to US-50 at Scipio; southeast on US-50 to Salina and US-89; south on US-89 to I-70; southwest on I-70 to I-15. huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM. The National Park Service manages Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and Horse Shoe National Park. These areas are interspersed with SITLA land. There is is also private land on Mt. Ellen, Mt. Hillers, and leased land on Mt. Holmes.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: There are no DWR Wildlife Management Areas
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There are three managed campgrounds on the Henry Mtns. Two on Mt Ellen: Lonesome Beaver and McMillan, and Mt. Hillers: Star Springs. Direct questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Hanksville BLM Field Office. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield/recreation_/henry_mountains.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
Deer, Bison, Elk: There are several Henry Mountain access roads. Mount Ellen can be accessed on the North from the Sawmill Basin road, travel south on 100 East in Hanksville. Access to the east side of Mt Ellen is from the Little Egypt road at mile marker 20 off of SR95. Access to the west side of Ellen and Pennell is off the Notom/Burr Trail road, turn east at the Sandy Ranch. The east side of Mount Pennell and the north side of Mount Hillers can be accessed from the Coyote Benches/Stanton Pass road off of SR276. The east and south side of Mount Hillers can be accessed from the Star Springs road also off of SR276. All these roads connect with each other so there is general access to various areas across the mountain range.The BLM has put up good signage to get you around.

Desert Bighorn Sheep: Some of the best access is from Lake Powell on the east side of the unit. From the lake you can access Trachyte, Two Mile, Four Mile, Peshliki, and Ticaboo drainages. SR95 through North Wash follows along the North side of the unit and hwy 276 which travels along the west side of Mt. Holmes and Elsworth and the east side Mt. Hillers. From the map you will see a few stem roads going east off of SR276. One accesses Trachyte Point for about 3 miles where it ends above Hog Springs. Another road stems towards Mt. Holmes and Fred Ridge but this soon dead ends at a private property gate. Another road stems also to Mt. Ellsworth. Ticaboo Mesa is also accessed from SR276, this road runs along the southern side of Mt. Ellsworth and overlooks the canyon forks of Ticaboo Creek and other canyons and mesas to the North.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS:
The following link on the BLM website provides a good map of the general boundaries of the five BLM Wilderness Study Areas (WSAs) located in the hunt unit surrounding the Henry Mountains, as well as the motorized travel designations which presently exist on public lands in this area. This map is available at: https://www.blm.gov/sites/blm.gov/files/uploads/BLMUtahHenryMountainsMap.pdf
USGS maps are available at the BLM in Hanksville: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Escalante, Hanksville, Hite Crossing, and Loa. They have a general map that labels most of the main roads. The BLM also has good road signage to help you navigate.
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO:
Emery County: http://www.emerycounty.com/road/contact.htm
Wayne County: http://www.waynecountyutah.org/
Garfield County: http://garfield.utah.gov/
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Deer and Bison: 4 wheel drive is highly recommended on the Henry Mountains. Roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, Wayne and Garfield counties, and SITLA, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. The Cave Flat road has a temporary closure November 1st – May 15th. Direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Hanksville BLM Field Office, SITLA, and the county you are traveling. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield/recreation_/henry_mountains.html

Desert Bighorn: The few stem roads east off of SR276 would be best with an ATV. Direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Hanksville BLM Field Office, SITLA, and the county you are traveling.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Capital Reef National Park (CRNP). CRNP strictly regulates all hunting activity and access through the Park which is limited to the Swap Canyon trail on foot or by horse. At the end of the Cow Bison Orientation is detailed information about bison hunting and CRNP. You can see the orientation here. Contact Capital Reef National park for more information. http://www.nps.gov/care/contacts.htm

There is private property on both Mount Ellen and Mount Hillers. Mount Holmes also has private leased property. Written permission from the landowner/lessee is required by law to access and hunt private land.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Garfield, Kane and Wayne counties--Boundary begins on SR-95 at a point two miles south of Hanksville; south on SR-95 to Lake Powell; south along the west shore of Lake Powell to SR-276 at Bullfrog; north on SR-276 to the Burr Trail-Notom road; north on this road to the Capitol Reef National Park boundary; north on this boundary to the Burr Trail-Notom road at The Narrows and Divide Canyon; north on this road to a point two miles south of SR-24; east along a line that is two miles south of SR-24 to SR-95. EXCLUDES ALL NATIONAL PARKS. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Escalante, Hanksville, Hite Crossing, Loa. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700.

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Access is very limited.  Safest route is through Glade Park CO.  There is also access to the Dolores Triangle by crossing the Dolores River, but this route can be impassible depending on river conditions (use caution).

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The Anthro unit contains large amounts of Tribal Trust Lands. All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands and must be trailered on access roads across Tribal Lands.  For information on which roads are legal access roads contact Duchesne County. There are also several large areas of private land on the unit, including 1 large CWMU. Hunters must receive written permission before hunting private lands.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of the land within this unit is managed by federal and state land management agencies and thus open to hunting with general season permits but not Private Land Only permits. There are several large ranches within the unit, several of which are enrolled in the CWMU program for Big game. Consult accurate land ownership maps before going afield.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: <u>Campground information:</u> There are many improved Camping areas on the Fish Lake unit, both public and private. Good camping exists in Gooseberry area, Elk Horn, multiple areas around Fish Lake and Johnson Reservoir. Primitive camping is allowed on much of the BLM and USFS managed lands. There is one improved campground managed by the Piute tribe near Koosharem reservoir. During early spring some campgrounds are not accessible or open. Contact the managing agency for detailed information.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are many ways to access this unit. During the winter and early spring many of these roads (especially the upper elevation sections) may be closed due to snow. The north end can be accessed off of I-70 at the Gooseberry exit and also at the Hwy 72 exit. There are also many smaller unimproved roads that get you into good country from the frontage road along I-70. Access to the eastern side of the unit is via hwy 72. Roads that fork from hwy 72 that get you into good county include the Last Chance road, Road #206 that gets you onto the Thousand Lake Mountain, road #036 that takes you past Mill Meadow Reservoir and to Fish Lake.  There are many ATV trails and smaller unimproved roads that fork off of Hwy 72. The main access on the south end is SR-25 to Fish Lake via SR-24.   The west side is accessed via several dirt roads including the Hancock Flat road off of SR-25,  Road #053 that forks off of SR-24 gets you into the Rex Reservoir, and the Lost Creek country.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100.000 Maps: Loa, Salina. Fish Lake National Forest Travel Map
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: see ATV access
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: There is an expansive road and trail system on this unit. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, USFS, Sevier and Wayne counties. Most Travel regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated to the Fish Lake National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield and Loa. The USFS has a travel map that covers most of this area.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are several large tracts of private property on this unit. Several of these tracts are enrolled in the CWMU program and require special permits to hunt on them. Consult a good map to ensure you know where you are and to avoid any trespass conflicts

huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
This subunit is largely private lands with BLM and SITLA lands occurring in and near the canyons. There are no official campgrounds on this subunit. Camping on public lands is permitted. Please direct all questions regarding camping to the Bureau of Land Management or Utah State Institutional Trust Lands. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/monticello/recreation/activities/camping.html
SITLA: http://trustlands.utah.gov/business-groups/surface/recreational-use-of-trust-lands/
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
Horsehead/Coalbed/Monument Canyons – These canyons are on the Northeast side of the subunit.  Elk will travel between and bed down in these canyons during the day.
Cedar Park-Sagebrush parks with interlaced pinyon/juniper trees on the edges.  Can be a good area for the later hunts.
Cedar/Bug Point-These points contain large tracts of private property with agricultural fields.  Elk will move onto these fields during the night and can occasionally been seen during the day time.  Written permission is required to hunt these areas.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION Central Federal Lands Highway Division (CFLHD), in partnership with Wasatch County, Utah County, and the United States Forest Service (USFS) is planning to improve Strawberry Sheep Creek Road, a 31.9 mile route between US-6 and US-40. This road is really 
ROAD CLOSURE CONSIDERATIONS The key objective is to construct these roadway improvements while minimizing impacts to public users. To facilitate public safety, certain segments of the road will be closed during various construction activities. When the road is open, delays up to 30 minutes can be expected. The construction schedule is subject to change. During road closures, no motorized vehicles will be permitted on the route. Adjacent Off Highway Vehicle (OHV) trail routes will continue to be open during road closures. Where a potential conflict between an OHV and construction equipment is possible, the OHV access will be restricted for public safety. Emergency access will be permitted at all times.
ROAD CLOSURE PRELIMINARY SCHEDULE
a combination of three smaller routes, Sheep Creek – Rays Valley Road (FR 70051); Unicorn Ridge – Indian Creek Road (FR 70042); and West Side Strawberry Road (FR 70131). The construction work will be split into four segments: Segment 1 (FR 70051) begins at the MP 0.0 (intersection with US-6) and ends at MP 7.0 (FR 70042). The work on Segment 1 consists of pavement rehabilitation including patching, crack sealing, and chip sealing. Segment 2 and Segment 3 (FR 70042) begins at MP 7.0 and ends at FR 70131. The work on Segment 2 and 3 consists of roadway bench widening, paving, drainage improvements, and safety improvements. Segment 4 (FR 70131) begins at the intersection with FR 70042 and ends 3.75 miles north of the intersection. The work on Segment 4 consists of pavement rehabilitation, pulverizing, and paving with subexcavation as needed.
QUESTIONS? Wasatch County Public Works 1891 West 3000 South Heber City, Utah 84032 435-654-1661 www.wasatch.utah.gov

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
Bighorn Sheep: Access Points include the Woodside Road along the Price River. This will access the top of the Beckwith Plateau but will require an ATV. Be careful crossing the Price River especially if it has rained recently. This road is found along SR-6 about 35 miles south of Price. An additional access is the Horse Canyon Road on SR-6 about 25 miles south of Price. This will provide access to the cliffs above Horse Canyon and Lila Canyon. Some hunters will drive the Hastings Road on the east side of the Green River in the town of Green River. From this road you can glass across the river to the cliffs on the west side of the river. You will obviously need some sort of boat to cross the river.

Pronghorn:Major access points include the following roads (all are accessed via SR-6); the Coal Creek Road in Wellington, the Soldier Creek Road in Wellington, the Clark Valley Road, SR-123 near Sunnyside, the Horse Canyon Road, and the Lila Canyon Road.

Mule Deer: Major access points include the Nine Mile Canyon road found at the east end of Wellington and the Bruin Point Road which is accessed via SR-123 going through the town of Sunnyside. These two roads will access much of the public lands on the West Tavaputs Plateau.

Elk: The major access points for elk hunting will be the Bruin Point road which is accessed via SR-123 through the town of Sunnyside, the Argyle Canyon road near the top of the summit of US-191 between Price and Duchesne, and the Nine Mile Canyon road out of the town of Wellington.

Bison: The Horse Canyon Road is found 25 miles south of Price on SR-6. This accesses the Range Creek area via Horse Canyon or Turtle Canyon. The Nine Mile Canyon Road in the town of Wellington will provide access to the Sand Wash Boat Ramp for floating Desolation Canyon

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
Bighorn Sheep: No Significant issues. Some private lands near Sunnyside and Horse Canyon.

Pronghorn: Private lands make up a small portion of pronghorn habitat, but pronghorn tend to use irrigated hayfields in late summer which are privately owned. These areas can be avoided. Some landowners provide access to hunters. Please secure permission prior to hunting. Pockets of private lands can be found in lower Coal Creek near Wellington, and portions of Icelander Wash southwest of Sunnyside.

Mule Deer and elk: the vast majority of the high elevation summer and fall habitat is on private land. There are a few small pockets of public land that can be found on the Cold Springs WMA east of Sunnyside, Cottonwood Ridge, and Harmon Canyon. Make sure you have a map or GPS depicting land ownership as there is an abundance of private land and it is essential that you know where you are.

Bison: A large part of the area where bison reside in Range Creek is managed by the Natural History Museum of Utah. You must have an access permit to be on this property and it is walk in or horseback only. Please visit https://nhmu.utah.edu/range-creek/visitor-permits to get an access permit. These permits are in short supply.

huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Elbow Ranch WMA - The Elbow Ranch WMA is a large winter range area. Do not expect high numbers of big game or bears to use this area during most hunting seasons.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There is only one official campground located on the unit. This campground is owned by the Koosharem Band of Piutes and is located adjacent to Koosharem reservoir. Hotel/camping accommodations exist in cities and towns that surround the unit. There is also a nearby campground at Otter Creek State Park. Camping outside of official campgrounds is permitted on most public ground. Please direct camping questions to the appropriate land management agency. Fishlake National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/fishlake
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are several main access roads to the Monroe unit. You can access the north side via road #068 from either the town of Annabella or Glenwood. This is a well maintained gravel road. From the east side you can take road #076 out of Koosharem and #069 out of Greenwich. Road #069 is the best road to take if you are pulling camp a trailer. The south end of the mountain can be accessed with the Pole canyon road (#072) near Angle or the Monroe Mountain road (#068) near Kingston. Both of these are maintained but are rather narrow and not recommended for large trailers. To access the west side of the unit use the Dry Creek road (#071) or the Monroe Canyon road (#078). Both of these roads are not recommended for trailers.

huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV and Vehicle Access: The Monroe unit has an extensive road and trail system. Many good areas to hunt can be accessed via vehicle. During the early hunting seasons most all roads and trails can be accessed. During later seasons early and heavy snows may make travel difficult. Some trails are restricted to ATVs of a certain size only. Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/fishlake/maps-pubs

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: You can access the south end of the unit from the Tom Best Spring road off of HWY 12. The west side of the unit can be accessed by several points from Circleville to Panguitch along HWY 89. I would access the top of the mountain using the Jones Corral or Cottonwood loop road.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Land Ownership: Public, Private, State Trust Lands (SITLA). The public lands are Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and Dixie National Forest managed out of the Cedar City and St. George Field Offices, respectively. Ninety percent of the deer habitat is on public lands. There is one CWMU on the unit. The New Harmony CWMU is for deer and turkey. Information on maps can be found at: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/res/utah_public_room/maps.print.html http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/dixie/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are BLM and USFS campgrounds on the unit. Baker Dam campground for BLM lands is near Veyo. Some campgrounds on USFS land are Oak Grove, Honeycomb Rocks, and Pine Valley reservoir. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the BLM and the USFS. Cedar City and St. George BLM website: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/cedar_city/recreation.html
St. George Forest Service website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/dixie/recreation/ohv

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  The public lands are all US Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley and Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forests and some BLM land on the Bonanza portion of the unit.  This unit includes a large portion of the High Uintas Wilderness Area where all motor vehicles are prohibited.  The western portion of this unit  includes large tracks of Ute Tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members.  The Tribal lands are mostly the lower elevation sagebrush areas but in some areas they reach up into the aspen/conifer zone.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit too.  Most of the private property is the lower elevation agricultural areas.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Montez Creek, Kevin Conway, Stewart Lake WMAs
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Most campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US National Forest Service. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. There are special restrictions on camping and campfires in certain areas within the Wilderness Area. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites. Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
Some campsites are also available at State Parks by Starvation, Red Fleet and Steinaker reservoirs. Questions regarding those campsites should be directed to Utah State Parks.https://stateparks.utah.gov/parks/

Maps can also be purchased online at: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The hunt unit does not include Ute Tribal lands as shown on the hunt boundary map on the Division's website.  There is a large tract of Ute Tribal Trust Land that stretches east to west across the South Slope of the Uintas.  Road access across the Tribal land is permitted only across the main access roads to the Forest.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal Lands

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Most of the summer and fall elk habitat is on public lands managed by the Forest Service.  There are however large tracts of private lands on the northeast portion of the unit in the area surrounding Scofield Reservoir.  Late Season Rifle hunters will have a little more private land to deal with as bulls transition to lower elevations.

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are no tribal lands to contend with. The vast majority of the early bull elk hunt habitat is on public land. A few exceptions include the following areas. The northeast portion of the mountain near Scofield Reservoir has a high percentage of private land on good elk habitat. Most of these lands are managed under the CWMU program and can not provide hunter access as your permit will not be valid on those properties. Other private properties require prior written permission before hunting. Small pockets of private lands at high elevations can be found surrounding Electric Lake and on East Mountain. Late Season any weapon hunters may encounter private lands in the Spring Canyon area west of Helper as well as upper Gordon Creek. Weather Conditions: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat. It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon. Be very cautious of lightening while hunting on high ridges. Early fall snow storms occur regularly in this area. Most years the snow will melt off, within a day or two until the first week of October.
